AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The percentage of total usable space on the selected logical disk drive that was free

AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The rate of read and write operations on the disk

AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The unallocated space, in megabytes, on the disk drive in megabytes

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Memory_Available MBytes
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The amount of physical memory, in Megabytes, immediately available for allocation to a process or for system use

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Memory_Committed Bytes
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The amount of committed virtual memory, in bytes

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Memory_Page Faults/sec
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The average number of pages faulted per second

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Memory_Pages Input/sec
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The rate at which pages are read from disk to resolve hard page faults

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Memory_Pages Output/sec
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The rate at which pages are written to disk to free up space in physical memory

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Memory_Pages/sec
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The rate at which pages are read from or written to disk to resolve hard page faults

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Memory_Pool Nonpaged Bytes
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The size, in bytes, of the nonpaged pool, an area of system memory (physical memory used by the operating system) for objects that cannot be written to disk, but must remain in physical memory as long as they are allocated

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Memory_Pool Paged Bytes
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The size, in bytes, of the paged pool, an area of system memory (physical memory used by the operating system) for objects that can be written to disk when they are not being used

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Paging File(_Total)_% Usage
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The Page File instance in use in percent

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: PhysicalDisk(_Total)_% Disk Time
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The percentage of elapsed time that the selected disk drive was busy servicing read or write requests

AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The average number of both read and write requests that were queued for the selected disk during the sample interval
AFAttributeTemplate.ConfigString: \\%@\zzz.GlobalConfiguration|PIDataArchiveName%\%@Target%_PhysicalDisk(_Total)_Avg. Disk Queue Length;ptclassname=classic;pointtype=Float32;descriptor="%Description%";pointsource="%@Target|PERFMON Point Source%";location1="%@Target|Location 1%";location4="%@Target|Location 4%";exdesc="\\%@Target%\PhysicalDisk(_Total)\Avg. Disk Queue Length"

AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The current size, in bytes, of memory that this process has allocated that cannot be shared with other processes

AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The average rate, in incidents per second, at which the processor received and serviced hardware interrupts

AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The number of times an internal Server Error was detected

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: System_Context Switches/sec
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The combined rate at which all processors on the computer are switched from one thread to another

AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The number of processes in the computer at the time of data collection

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: System_Processor Queue Length
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The number of threads in the processor queue

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: System_System Calls/sec
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The combined rate of calls to operating system service routines by all processes running on the computer

AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The elapsed time (in seconds) that the computer has been running since it was last started

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: System_Threads
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The number of threads in the computer at the time of data collection

Property.Name: Subject
Property.Value: <FlowDocument PagePadding="5,0,5,0" AllowDrop="True" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation" xmlns:osiann="clr-namespace:OSIsoft.AN.Notification;assembly=OSIsoft.AF.Notification.DeliveryChannel.Email" xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml"><Paragraph><osiann:ANInlineContent ContentID="15628018-3792-4aad-b13f-ad324c406a84" ContentProperty="2" PersistedContentName="" AdditionalData="" /><osiann:ANInlineContent ContentID="418df2db-58ed-4c27-97de-0a909bd8b2fe" ContentProperty="0" PersistedContentName="" AdditionalData="" /></Paragraph></FlowDocument>

Property.Name: Body
Property.Value:
Event: Start Time: Machine: Severity: Send Time: The maximum latency of the PI Analysis Service is higher than recommended and a PI Analysis Health Check should be performed.Critical Performance IndicatorCurrent ValueHealthy Limit
Possible causes:CPU and/or memory on the PI Analysis machine are limitedPI Analysis Service can't connect to the PI Data ArchiveOne ore more calculations are expensive and overloading the PI Analysis ServiceThe parameter "CalculationWaitTimeInSeconds" is set high. This parameter dictates how long a calculation waits to run once it is triggered to allow for all inputs to be received. The maximum latency includes this time.Troubleshooting Steps:Check the CPU and\or memory on the PI Analysis machine are not limited and connection to the PI Data ArchiveLog onto Check Performance counter, CPU and RAM should not be close to 100% usageCheck the connection to the Data Archive Server using the PI SDK UtilityPerform a PI Analysis Check to identify which calculations are experiencing the most latencyInformation regarding Troubleshooting the PI Analysis Service Performance is found in the following KB 01664.Follow the link to access this KB: Check the parameter "CalculationWaitTimeInSeconds". The default for this is 5 seconds, if it is long it will effect the maximum latencyFrom PI System Explorer, navigate to the Management TabRight Click in the right panel under Operations or Pending OperationsChoose "Edit Analysis Service Configuration"The parameter is in seconds. Modify if needed.
Link to PIVision for details about this Event: The PI System object or component generating this alert is:

Property.Name: Importance
Property.Value: Normal

Property.Name: Importance
Property.Value: Normal

Property.Name: Subject
Body
Property.Value:
: : Severity: Target Machine (Host): Max Total Queued Events:
Critical Performance IndicatorsCurrent ValueHealthy LimitOverall Health Indicator: not "OK"
Event: Event Start Time: Target Machine (Host): Current Point Count: PI Vision: AF Server: AF Database: Ensure that the Windows service for the PI Buffer Subsystem is running on the Target host machine.The Windows Performance Monitor counters shown above correspond to the global status of the PI Buffer Subsystem object in Windows Performance Monitor. Windows Performance Monitor Counters specific to each buffered server are available. This template can be extended to include them if you want to differentiate which receiving PI server having issues. OSIsoft provides documentation of the PI Buffer Subsystem online. Here you can read more detail about healthy and unhealthy operations.

AFElementTemplate.Name: PI Data Archive
AFElementTemplate.Description: PI Data Archive

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Archive Compression Ratio
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: Daily archive compression ratio the ratio should be no less than 3, a ratio of 1 means no compression is applied

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Archive Corruption Status
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: Bad when the when a corrupted archive was detected, the value will show good if 0 corrupted archives or if the input is bad (to avoid false positive on bad values)
AFAttributeTemplate.ConfigString: C=PI Archive Subsystem: Set(Historical)_Corrupted Archives Count;UOM=count;[if badval(C) then 0 else if (C==0) then 0 else 1];stepped=True

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Archive Rate Status
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: Bad when the archiving rate goes to 0 or when the rate tag has a bad value, also bad when archiving is disabled
AFAttributeTemplate.ConfigString: A=Average Archiving Rate;UOM=Events/Sec;F=PI Archive Subsystem: Set(Historical)_Archiving Flag;R=PI Archive Subsystem: Set(Historical)_Archived Events/sec;UOM=Events/Sec;[if (badval(A) or badval(F) or badval(R)) then 1 else if (F==0) then 1 else if (A<1) then 1 else 0];stepped=True

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Archive_CacheRecordPool_per_point
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: Maximum number of archive cache records for read access queries. The actual size of the read-only cache pool may lower due to low physical memory resources. Divide the value of the tuning parameter by the number of PI Points

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Archive_MaxWriteCachePerPoint
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: Maximum number of write cache events per point. Events of a given point will be flushed to disk when this limit is exceeded.

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Average Archive Read
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: Average Archiving Read 10 minutes

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Average Archiving Rate
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: Average Archiving Rate 10 minutes

AFAttributeTemplate.Description: Average Snapshot Rate 10 minutes

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Average Snapshot Read
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: Average Snapshot Read 10 minutes

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Cache Reads bar
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: Cache Reads bar provides a metric of how busy the PI Archive Subsystem is with clients requests. This meter considers the number of points on the PI Server and the maximum number of records allowed per points in the cache which is given by the Tuning Parameter “Archive_CacheRecordPool”.

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Cache Writes bar
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: Cache Writes bar
AFAttributeTemplate.ConfigString: A=Archive_MaxWriteCachePerPoint;P=PI Base Subsystem_Point Count;UOM=count;T=PI Archive Subsystem: Set(Historical)_Total Unflushed Events;UOM=Events;[100*T/(A*P)];UOM=%

AFNotificationRuleTemplate.Name: Archive Corruption Alert
AFNotificationRuleTemplate.Description: Detects if some archives are corrupted

Property.Name: Subject
Property.Value: generated a new notification event.

Property.Name: Body
Property.Value:
Event: Start Time: Machine: Severity: Send Time: Start Trigger: Start Trigger Expression: The PI Archive Subsystem has detected archive corruption. One or more historical archive files are currently corrupted. These archives need to be reprocessed to fix the issue. You can access the list of Archive from PI SMT -> Operations -> Archives . Look at the Corrupt column to know which Archives are corrupted. Critical Performance IndicatorCurrent ValueHealthy Limit0, there should not be any corrupted archivesValue must be 1, if 0 data is not being archived>0Value should be 0
Troubleshooting steps- The preferred way to reprocess archives it to use the online reprocessing capability in PI SMT. More information can be found here:- If the online reprocessing cannot be used then the offline archive utility (piarchss) must be used.Link to this event in PI Vision PI Data Archive Overview in Vision The PI System object or component generating this alert is:

Property.Name: Importance
Property.Value: Normal

Property.Name: Subject
Property.Value: <FlowDocument PagePadding="5,0,5,0" AllowDrop="True" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation" xmlns:osiann="clr-namespace:OSIsoft.AN.Notification;assembly=OSIsoft.AF.Notification.DeliveryChannel.Email" xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml"> <Paragraph xml:space="preserve"> <osiann:ANInlineContent ContentID="15628018-3792-4aad-b13f-ad324c406a84" ContentProperty="2" PersistedContentName="" /> </Paragraph> </FlowDocument>

AFNotificationRuleTemplate.Name: Archive Shift Failed
AFNotificationRuleTemplate.Description: The last archive shift failed to create a new archive

Property.Name: Subject
Property.Value: generated a new notification event.

Property.Name: Body
Property.Value:
Event: Start Time: Machine: Severity: Send Time: Start Trigger: Start Trigger Expression: The last PI Archive shift failed . When this happens archiving is disabled on the PI Data Archive and data should start accumulating in the event queue until the issue is fixed. When the issue with the archive file is fixed and a shift is successful Archiving will be enabled.The fix for this issue will depend on what the cause is.Critical Performance IndicatorCurrent ValueHealthy Limit010>0
Possible causes:- Insufficient disk space for the drive of the primary archive.- Make sure auto archive creation is enabled in the tuning parameters.- Some other issues can also cause a failure during an archive shift.Troubleshooting Steps:- Verify that auto archive creation is enabled and pointing to a valid folder.- Check the primary Archive disk space. You can find this from PI SMT -> Operations -> Archives look at free disk space at the top.-Add more disk space if needed to create new archives, then restart the PI Archive Subsystem- If the disk space is not the issue and if auto archive creation is enabled (tuning parameters: Archive_AutoArchiveFileRoot) then contact OSIsoft Tech Support to troubleshoot the issue.Link to this event in PI Vision PI Data Archive Overview in Vision The PI System object or component generating this alert is:

Property.Name: Importance
Property.Value: Normal

AFNotificationRuleTemplate.Name: Archiving Failure Alert
AFNotificationRuleTemplate.Description: Detects if the PI Archive Subsystem stops archiving data

Property.Name: Subject
Property.Value: generated a new notification event.

Property.Name: Body
Property.Value:
Event: Start Time: Machine: Severity: Send Time: Archiving has been disabled . When this happens the data should start accumulating in the event queue until the issue is fixed. This issue does not usually result in data loss because when Archiving is re-enabled the data from the event queue will be sent to the archive files.The fix for this issue will depend on what the cause is.Critical Performance IndicatorCurrent ValueHealthy Limit10>00
Possible causes:- Insufficient disk space for the drive of the primary archive which could also cause an failed archive shift- Make sure auto archive creation is enabled in the tuning parameters.- Some other issues can disable archiving. For the reason why archiving has been disabled, check the PI Server Message Log, in particular message ID # 2207.Troubleshooting Steps:- Verify that auto archive creation is enabled and pointing to a valid folder.- Check the primary Archive disk space. You can find this from PI SMT -> Operations -> Archives look at free disk space at the top.-Add more disk space if needed to create new archives, then restart the PI Archive Subsystem- If the disk space is not the issue and if auto archive creation is enabled (tuning parameters: Archive_AutoArchiveFileRoot) then contact OSIsoft Tech Support to troubleshoot the issue.Link to this event in PI Vision PI Data Archive Overview in Vision The PI System object or component generating this alert is:

Property.Value: Normal

AFNotificationRuleTemplate.Description: Help to detect high cache read utilization

Property.Name: Subject
Property.Value: generated a new notification event.

Property.Name: Body
Property.Value:
Event: Start Time: Machine: Severity: Send Time: Start Trigger: Start Trigger Expression: The PI System has detected a high utilization ratio of the cache read.Read performance for client applications could be impacted.Critical Performance IndicatorCurrent ValueHealthy LimitTarget: <= Hi: Max: Target: <= Hi: Max: Target: <= Hi: Max:
Common symptoms:- PI ProcessBook or PI Vision trends taking a long time to load- PI ProcessBook becomes unresponsive- PE calculations or analyses are delayed- It takes long time to retrieve archive data or the request times out ( [-10722] PINET: Timeout on PI RPC or System Call)- PI Archive Subsystem does not respond to any request- Errors " [-16212] Timeout attempting to get non-exclusive lock" and " [-16214] Timeout attempting to get exclusive lock" in PI message logs- Tag operations take a long time or fails due to PI Archive Subsystem lack of responsiveness- The users could experiencing read performance issues, if this is the case then you can find more information on troubleshooting see: Link to this event in PI Vision PI Data Archive Overview in Vision The PI System object or component generating this alert is:

Property.Name: Importance
Property.Value: Normal

Property.Name: Subject
Property.Value: generated a new notification event.

Property.Name: Body
Property.Value:
Event: Start Time: Machine: Severity: Send Time: Start Trigger: Start Trigger Expression: There seems to be a problem with the Event Queue on . Events have been accumulating in the Event Queue and not flushing fast enough to the archives or not flushing at all. Some issues that could cause this are a corrupted primary Archive or a corrupted Event Queue.Critical Performance IndicatorCurrent ValueHealthy LimitClose to 0, can be a positive number, but should go back to zero and it should not ramp up.1>0>0, zero indicates that the data could be stuck in the queue0, a corrupted primary Archive would cause the events to accumulate in the Queue1, 0 means the data is not archiving
Troubleshooting steps:Note: if at any point you are unsure what is causing the issue or whether the archive file or event queue is corrupted, please Contact OSIsoft technical support for assistance fixing the issue.If the Event queue is corrupted you can have a look at the following article.If the primary archive is corrupted have a look at the following articles:- The preferred way to reprocess archives it to use the online reprocessing capability in PI SMT. More information can be found here:- If the online reprocessing cannot be used then the offline archive utility (piarchss) must be used.Link to this event in PI Vision PI Data Archive Overview in Vision The PI System object or component generating this alert is:

AFNotificationRuleTemplate.Name: Out of Order Event Alert
AFNotificationRuleTemplate.Description: High Out of Order Event percentage can affect performance
AFNotificationRuleTemplate.Criteria: AnalysisName:"Out of Order Events Alert" "|Start Trigger Name":<>Out_of_Order_Events_Ratio

Property.Name: Subject
Property.Value: generated a new notification event.

Property.Name: Body
Property.Value:
Event: Start Time: Machine: Severity: Send Time: Start Trigger: Start Trigger Expression: The PI System has detected a high ratio of Out of Order Events .Out of order data can possibly impact the performance of your PI Data Archive and the source values for calculated tags.High rates of out of order data can negatively impact PI Archive subsystem performance. When data arrive at the PI Data Archive in order, the PI Archive subsystem adds the value to the end of a point's record in the archive file. However, when data come to the PI Data Archive out of order, the PI Archive subsystem must continuously move aside existing data to make room for the old data. This puts an extra load on the PI Archive subsystem and can make it less responsive to other tasks.Critical Performance IndicatorCurrent ValueHealthy LimitTarget: <= Hi: Max: Target: <= Hi: Max: >0>0Minimum: LoLo: Lo: Target: 1
Common causes:- PI Data Archive, interface, or data source clock drift- Backfilling (PI to PI Interface, PI Interface for OPC HDA, PI Interface for UFL, ...)- Interface failover + buffering (failover occurs while buffering and then the primary sends its buffered data before the backup)- For more details on causes and solutions see: Link to this event in PI Vision PI Data Archive Overview in Vision The PI System object or component generating this alert is:

Property.Value: Normal

AFElementTemplate.Name: PI Interface Instance without Failover
AFElementTemplate.Description: Monitors a PI Universal Interface with single node

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: (_Total)_Interface Heartbeat
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The value written to the heartbeat tag increments from a value starting at 1, increments to a value of 15 and then restarts at 1.

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: (_Total)_Interface up-time (seconds)
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The amount of time (in seconds) that this Interface has been running.

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: (_Total)_PI Status
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: Store communication information about the interface and the connection to the PI Server. 0 if the interface is properly communicating with the PI Server, 1 if the communication to the PI Server goes down for any reason.
AFAttributeTemplate.TypeQualifier: EnumerationSets[PI Interface to PI Data Archive Communication Status]

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: (_Total)_Point Count
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The number of PI Points per interface instance

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: (_Total)_Points Good
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The number of points that have sent a good current value to PI.

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: (_Total)_Points In Error

Body

Critical Performance IndicatorCurrent ValueHealthy Limit

Property.Name: Subject
Body
Property.Value:
Event: Start Time: Machine: Interface Name: Interface ID: Pointsource: Severity: Send Time: Start Trigger: Start Trigger Expression: There is % missed or % skipped scans from the PI Interface instance through point source with interface ID . Missed or skipped scans is critical because there is data loss.Interface Specifications:MachineIssue
Critical Performance IndicatorCurrent ValueHealthy Limit
Possible causes:- scan frequency might be too fast- this interface instance might be overloaded- possibly drop packets with network issueTroubleshooting Steps:- review each scan class correspond to PI Interface instance- determine which scan class has missed and skipped scans from the attributes Scheduled Scans: % Missed and Scheduled Scans: % Skipped.- increase the time of the scan rate if it is too fast for the PI Interface to handle or create another interface instance to ease of the load if there is too many tagsLink to this event in PI Vision The PI System object or component generating this alert is:

Property.Name: Subject
Property.Value: <FlowDocument PagePadding="5,0,5,0" AllowDrop="True" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation" xmlns:osiann="clr-namespace:OSIsoft.AN.Notification;assembly=OSIsoft.AF.Notification.DeliveryChannel.Email" xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml"><Paragraph><osiann:ANInlineContent ContentID="15628018-3792-4aad-b13f-ad324c406a84" ContentProperty="2" PersistedContentName="" AdditionalData="" /><Run xml:lang="en-ca" xml:space="preserve"> </Run><osiann:ANInlineContent ContentID="9cfcde7e-9975-4aca-a6ba-47dc17119902" ContentProperty="0" PersistedContentName="" AdditionalData="" /></Paragraph></FlowDocument>

Property.Name: Body
Property.Value:
Event: Start Time: Machine: Interface Name: Interface ID: Pointsource: Severity: Send Time: Start Trigger: Start Trigger Expression: The PI Interface on has detected the following health issue: . For more information look at the table and steps below. Interface Specifications:MachineIssue
Interface Status:Critical Performance IndicatorCurrent ValueHealthy Limit0 | Connected / Receiving DataValue updating between 1-15,0 means shutdown17-31 means no connection to PI>=0
Troubleshooting steps:- Use PI System Explorer to look at the health of the interface.- Open PI System Explorer and navigate to the Element: . Look at the attribute value to see the current value of the Device status and the heartbeat.- Look a the current value of the tags using PI SMT > Current Values , search for point source " ".- Look at the data tag (tags coming from the data source) to see if they are updating.- If the device status is still bad or if the heartbeat is not updating the interface service might need to be restarted.- If the issue is still not resolved after restarting the interface or the get more detail about the issue look at the PI Message logs on the interface node.- If you need help troubleshooting the issue you can contact OSIsoft Tech Support .For more information about interface status tags:Link to this event in PI Vision The PI System object or component generating this alert is:

Property.Value: Normal

AFAnalysisRule.ConfigString: State := if ('{966c7747-e27d-4e82-a0f8-2fcd7abdc63b};FailoverID'="1") then 'Interface 1 Failover State' else 'Interface 2 Failover State';

AFNotificationRuleTemplate.Name: No Longer Primary Alert
AFNotificationRuleTemplate.Description: Trigger a notification when a PI Interface instance switch from Primary to backup.

Property.Name: Subject
Body
Property.Value:
Event: Start Time: Machine: Interface Name: Interface ID: Pointsource: Severity: Send Time: Start Trigger: Start Trigger Expression: The PI Interface is no longer primary. Interface Specifications:MachineIssue
Critical Performance IndicatorCurrent ValueHealthy LimitPrimary or Backup
Possible causes:- the current state of the failover is Interface State: The failover state tags are digital tags assigned to the UFO_State digital set with the following values:0 Off: The interface has been shut down.1 Backup No Data Source: The interface is running but is unable to communicate to the data source.2 Backup No PI Connection: The interface is running and connected to the data source but has lost its communication to the PI Server.3 Backup: The interface is running and collecting data normally and is ready to take over if the primary shuts down or experiences problems.4 Transition: The interface stays in this state for only a short period of time. The transition period is designed to prevent thrashing when both primary and backup interfaces attempt to assume the role of the primary interface.5 Primary: The interface is running, collecting data, and sending the data to PI.Troubleshooting Steps:- check if the other pair is in "Primary" state to ensure there is no data loss.- restart the PI Interface- make sure the state is in "Backup" after restart- review the data flow from data source to PI Data Archive if restart doesn't help- contact OSIsoft Techsupport +1 510 297 5828 for helpLink to this event in PI Vision The PI System object or component generating this alert is:

Property.Value: Normal

AFNotificationRuleTemplate.Name: WatchDog Stale Alert
AFNotificationRuleTemplate.Description: Trigger a notification when the watchdog tag does not update.

Property.Name: Subject
Property.Value: <FlowDocument PagePadding="5,0,5,0" AllowDrop="True" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation" xmlns:osiann="clr-namespace:OSIsoft.AN.Notification;assembly=OSIsoft.AF.Notification.DeliveryChannel.Email" xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml"><Paragraph><Span /><osiann:ANInlineContent ContentID="15628018-3792-4aad-b13f-ad324c406a84" ContentProperty="2" PersistedContentName="" AdditionalData="" /><Run xml:lang="en-ca" xml:space="preserve"> </Run><osiann:ANInlineContent ContentID="9cfcde7e-9975-4aca-a6ba-47dc17119902" ContentProperty="0" PersistedContentName="" AdditionalData="" /></Paragraph></FlowDocument>

Property.Name: Body
Property.Value:
Event: Start Time: Machine: Interface Name: Pointsource: Severity: Send Time: Start Trigger: Start Trigger Expression: The PI System has detected that a watchdog Tag is not receiving new values. This is a tag should always be receiving data and is monitored to indicate interface health. This can be either an outage at the data source upstream of PI or a problem within PI. This event should be investigated quickly in order to find root causes and make corrections.Interface Specifications:MachineIssue
Critical Performance IndicatorCurrent ValueHealthy Limit > 0
Causes for stale bad data:- Network issues.- Shutdown of the PI Interface computer or service.- Connection issue with the data source.- Inadvertent modification of point attributes affecting data collection.For more information see: Troubleshooting steps:- Use PI System Explorer to look at the health of the interface.- Open PI System Explorer and navigate to the Element: . Look at the attribute value to see the current value of the failover attributes. Have a look at the parent Element to see the Heartbeat and Device Status- Look a the current value of the tags using PI SMT > Current Values , search for point source " ".- Look at the data tag (tags coming from the data source) to see if they are updating.- If none of the interfaces are in the primary state, the service might need to be restarted.- If the issue is still not resolved after restarting the interface or the get more detail about the issue look at the PI Message logs on the interface node.- If you need help troubleshooting the issue you can contact OSIsoft Tech Support .Link to this event in PI Vision The PI System object or component generating this alert is:

Property.Name: Importance
Property.Value: Normal

AFElementTemplate.Description: Applicable to PI Notifications 2016R2+

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Escalations in Progress
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: Number of active escalation teams in progress.
AFAttributeTemplate.ConfigString: \\%@\zzz.GlobalConfiguration|PIDataArchiveName%\%@Target%_PI_Notifications_%Attribute%;ptclassname=classic;pointtype=Float32;descriptor=%Description%;exdesc=\\%@Target%\PI Notifications Service\Escalations in progress;location1=%@Target|Location 1%;location4=%@Target|Location 4%;pointsource=%@Target|PERFMON Point Source%

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Escalations Scheduled
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: Number of escalation events scheduled since the start of the PI Notifications Service.

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Event Frame Changes Observed
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: Number of event frame changes received from the AF server since the start of the PI Notifications Service. Changes received cause notification instances to start, end, and change state.
AFAttributeTemplate.ConfigString: \\%@\zzz.GlobalConfiguration|PIDataArchiveName%\%@Target%_PI_Notifications_%Attribute%;ptclassname=classic;pointtype=Float32;descriptor=%Description%;exdesc=\\%@Target%\PI Notifications Service\Event Frame Changes Observed;location1=%@Target|Location 1%;location4=%@Target|Location 4%;pointsource=%@Target|PERFMON Point Source%

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Failed Sends
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: Number of failed send attempts since the start of the PI Notifications Service.

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Failed Sends / sec
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: Rate of failed send attempts per second. This counter displays the difference between the values observed in the last two samples divided by the duration of the sample interval. This counter is not an average over time.

Property.Name: Subject
Property.Value: <FlowDocument PagePadding="5,0,5,0" AllowDrop="True" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation" xmlns:osiann="clr-namespace:OSIsoft.AN.Notification;assembly=OSIsoft.AF.Notification.DeliveryChannel.Email" xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml"><Paragraph><osiann:ANInlineContent ContentID="9cfcde7e-9975-4aca-a6ba-47dc17119902" ContentProperty="0" PersistedContentName="" AdditionalData="" /></Paragraph></FlowDocument>

Property.Name: Body
Property.Value:
: : Severity:
Critical Performance IndicatorsCurrent ValueHealthy Limit
------------------------------------------------------Event: Event Start Time: Event End Time: Machine (Host): PI Vision: AF Server: AF Database: The trigger responsible for the notification is in the title. Both and are incremental since the Notifications service was started. The current value might be high but it's the differential between the curent value and 5 minutes ago that caused the notification.

Property.Name: Importance
Property.Value: Normal

AFAnalysisTemplate.Description: Calculate Average PING Reply Time

AFAnalysisRule.ConfigString: StartTime := TimeStamp('{bdec4ae0-4dff-4b7e-8f71-7f7ec6ac83ca};ReplyTime') - Convert('{774e0e0b-b453-4d8a-b3b8-036b4a2c2b98};ReplyTimeAverage|{003eec81-2bc4-46a9-830c-4d53a0ec4e18};TimeSpan',"s"); CalcAverage := TagAvg('{bdec4ae0-4dff-4b7e-8f71-7f7ec6ac83ca};ReplyTime', StartTime, '*');

AFAnalysisTemplate.Description: Detect High average PING reply time

AFAnalysisRule.ConfigString: EFTGUID=ec127ab7-b458-42f5-afc0-d4ff98db40f2;EFTNAME=PI System Monitoring Alert;SAVETRIGGEREXPRESSION=True;SAVETRIGGERNAME=True

@group("Start triggers") @name("Slow_Reply_Time") @severity("Warning") @timetrue("300") StartTrigger1 := '{774e0e0b-b453-4d8a-b3b8-036b4a2c2b98};ReplyTimeAverage'>'{774e0e0b-b453-4d8a-b3b8-036b4a2c2b98};ReplyTimeAverage|{e1d65114-7c5b-42e6-99af-9fccb7183d11};Hi';

Property.Name: Body
Property.Value:
: : Severity:
Critical Performance IndicatorsCurrent ValueHealthy LimitHealth Determined by Average PING TimeN/A
High PING reply time indicates slow network travel times. There are several possible causes. Here are are the most common causes:heavy network traffic at the timecongested/overloaded routers on the way to the target machinelow quality/inadequate bandwidth------------------------------------------------------Event: Event Start Time: Event End Time: Machine (Host): PI Vision: AF Server: AF Database: Provided by OSIsoft, LLC Delivery Services 2019

Property.Name: Importance
Property.Value: Normal

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Cache % Machine Memory Limit Used
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The amount of physical memory used by the machine divided by the physical memory limit for the cache, as a percentage. When this reaches 100%, half of the cache entries will be forcibly removed. The __Total__ instance is the average of all instances, and therefore cannot be used to determine when cache entries will be forcibly removed.
AFAttributeTemplate.ConfigString: \\%@\zzz.GlobalConfiguration|PIDataArchiveName%\%@Target%_%Attribute%;ptclassname=classic;pointtype=Float32;descriptor=%Description%;exdesc=\\%@Target%\ASP.NET Apps v4.0.30319(_LM_W3SVC_%@Target|ID%_ROOT_PIVision)\Cache % Machine Memory Limit Used;location1=%@Target|Location 1%;location4=%@Target|Location 4%;pointsource=%@Target|PERFMON Point Source%

AFAttributeTemplate.Name: Cache % Process Memory Limit Used
AFAttributeTemplate.Description: The value of private bytes for the worker process divided by the private bytes memory limit for the cache, as a percentage. When this reaches 100%, half of the cache entries will be forcibly removed. The __Total__ instance is the average of all instances, and therefore cannot be used to determine when cache entries will be forcibly removed.
AFAttributeTemplate.ConfigString: \\%@\zzz.GlobalConfiguration|PIDataArchiveName%\%@Target%_%Attribute%;ptclassname=classic;pointtype=Float32;descriptor=%Description%;exdesc=\\%@Target%\ASP.NET Apps v4.0.30319(_LM_W3SVC_%@Target|ID%_ROOT_PIVision)\Cache % Process Memory Limit Used;location1=%@Target|Location 1%;location4=%@Target|Location 4%;pointsource=%@Target|PERFMON Point Source%
